Tracy Karanja
        
              
          🚀 Week 2 Recap: Headstarter AI SWE Fellowship Journey! 🚀

I’m excited to share what I’ve been up to in my second week as part of the Headstarter AI Software Engineering Fellowship!

Week 1: Started off strong by learning how to build a portfolio website, thanks to the incredible guidance from Yasin Ehsan 🚀. His insights and support have been invaluable in crafting a standout portfolio.

Week 2: I dove into a new project – building a Pantry Tracker application! 🍽️ The tracker is a comprehensive tool for managing pantry inventory with features such as:

Add/Remove Items: Easily add or remove items with real-time updates.
Update Quantities: Adjust item quantities as needed.
Search Functionality: Quickly find items in your pantry.

Technologies Used: Leveraged React and Next JS for the frontend, Firebase for real-time database management, and Material UI for a sleek, responsive UI. The app integrates CRUD operations for a seamless user experience.
Thanks to Bill Zhang for his guidance on this project.

Here is the link to the desktop website if you're curious: https://lnkd.in/dydirkvC

And the github: https://lnkd.in/dfSWnVrR

🔗 Special Mentions:
Speakers: I had the privilege of attending an online panel discussion with industry leaders:
Dennis, Founder of Foursquare, with insights on scaling a $150M revenue company.
Tariq, the first SWE at Applovin, sharing his journey through a $30Bn IPO.
Julian, Ex-Meta SWE and Intern CEO of Wisdolia, discussing his path in tech.
Hamza, CEO of Olostep, who’s currently hiring Headstarter fellows.


Feeling grateful for these learning experiences and the opportunity to connect with such inspiring professionals! Here’s to continued growth and innovation. 🌟
#HeadstarterFellowship #SoftwareEngineering #PantryTracker #TechCommunity #Networking #Innovation

Prakhar Sinha
        
              
          A few short days ago, I wrapped up my research position at UC Davis Health with Professor Farzad Fereidouni. My role at the lab entailed a specialization in machine learning and computer vision and I'm excited to share what I was able to accomplish with everyone. 

I worked on two projects during my time at the lab. The first one was something I called "Kernel Generation for Image Similarity" (https://lnkd.in/ghsY73ts). It was to process an image such that it would look like it was H&E stained. I learned a lot about the basics of histology and digital histology through this process. The most novel part of this approach was using Wiener deconvolution to generate a kernel that would be used to enhance image similarity (typically using SSIM, MSE or a combination of both). 

A big part of this process was optimization. I learned how to use Python libraries such as Cupy and other tools to GPU accelerate a lot of these image-processing optimization problems.

My second project and my most meaningful contribution was called "FastSAM-needle-biopsy" (https://lnkd.in/gXXydq-X). The objective of this project was to use the FastSAM image segmentation network to accurately generate image segmentation masks of live tissue such that a microscope would only scan the relevant parts of an image. Here is step by step walkthrough of the image processing pipeline:

1) VB.NET (Darius) application calls a DLL (compiled from csharp.NET)
2) DLL calls FastSAM image segmentation code using Python.NET
3) FastSAM segments image and returns image segmentation bitmask and as well as the fastest path to visit every bit (Traveling Salesman Problem)
4) Python returns values are returned to DLL using JSON as a reliable data transfer solution 
5) DLL returns an object that can be parsed by VB.NET

FastSAM is a faster version of Meta Research's Segment Anything Model and I used it to greatly speed up development time on this project. It was a big challenge to integrate such cutting-edge, machine-learning driven, image processing pipelines into a legacy codebase that was written in Visual Basic .NET but thanks to tools such as DLLs, JSON, and C#, I was able to figure it out!

I am very grateful for the time I spent in the lab. I feel like I developed some great programming skills, especially in computer vision, that will prove useful for the rest of my career. I'd like to give special thanks to Professor Fereidouni, Ruby Mascareno, Willy Ju, Dena Sayrafi, Ruben Gnanaruban, Inyola, Antara Mallick, and Jayla. 

The link is here if you'd like to see my lab report going over everything I did in more technical detail and with a few pictures!

https://lnkd.in/gRpZVmjG

#computervision #machinelearning #AI #histology

Raj Abhijit Dandekar
        
              
          What society values may not be the best thing for you.

When I applied for grad school, I got admits from MIT, Stanford, Purdue, CMU and UIUC.

I knew I wanted to do a PhD. I chose MIT immediately, because it was ranked number 1. 

I never thought whether it was a good decision or not. 

I just assumed that it’s a good decision because it’s rated higher than the other universities.

When I joined MIT, all that rank 1 noise disappeared.

All I was surrounded by was my lab, my lab group members and my advisor. 

I had never carefully considered whether this research group was a good fit for me. I just joined the first MIT research group which came my way.

This led to a miserable first 2 years of PhD for me. 

The group was not a good fit and the research topic was also not a good fit.

These lost 2 years were a result of choosing what society values more (university ranking) rather than what is a better thing for me.

When I look back, I should have done the following:

(1) I should have made a list of all research groups I was interested in, from all universities I was selected to.

(2) I should have spoken with the lab advisor from all these research groups and understood their vision.

(3) I should have learnt more about the group culture by talking to past members of the group. Graduating members are usually very honest. They would tell you if the culture is toxic, if the advisor is micromanaging etc.

(4) I should have looked at the group website to look at the publication rate, what do the alumni end up doing etc? If the average graduation time is 8 years, it’s a red flag.

After doing the above 4 things, I should have selected the best research group for me.

I should have selected the research group whose culture aligns well with my personality.

Society values ranking. 

However, when you enter the university for a PhD, the ranking does not matter. Your research group matters. What you do every day after waking up matters.

And if you blindly select universities based on the ranking, the research group won’t be a good fit and it would lead to a terrible PhD experience.

It turns out that society misguides people in many other professions including:

- Choosing to prepare for IIT-JEE just because society prefers that you are an IITian
- Choosing a job just because society prefers higher salary
- Choosing to not do a startup because the society (your parents) don’t approve

Always question yourself before blindly making decisions based on what the society values. It might not be the best thing for you.

Going against traditional societal values is hard in the short term, but it pays off in the long run.

P.S: In the photo, you can see me during my first day at MIT!

Jonathan Ouyang
        
              
          My name is Jonathan Ouyang. I am a 𝑓𝑖𝑟𝑠𝑡 𝑦𝑒𝑎𝑟 at UCLA studying Computer Science. And I am the 𝐆𝐑𝐀𝐍𝐃 𝐏𝐑𝐈𝐙𝐄 𝐖𝐈𝐍𝐍𝐄𝐑 𝐎𝐅 𝐆𝐎𝐎𝐆𝐋𝐄’𝐒 𝐆𝐄𝐌𝐈𝐍𝐈 𝐀𝐏𝐈 𝐃𝐄𝐕𝐄𝐋𝐎𝐏𝐄𝐑 𝐂𝐎𝐌𝐏𝐄𝐓𝐈𝐓𝐈𝐎𝐍 🎉🎉.

It still doesn’t feel real to type all of this out. No amount of words in a LinkedIn post can describe exactly how I feel right now. I still can’t believe that I won the grand prize of a CUSTOM 1981 ELECTRIC DELOREAN CAR FROM BACK TO THE FUTURE ($200k Car + $60k Cash)

I am the sole developer of Jayu, a next-generation AI personal assistant that can directly interact with your computer screen. From controlling applications to writing code to giving live translations, Jayu was meant to show the world what Google Gemini is TRULY capable of. More than a chatbot, more than an LLM, Gemini is capable of bringing us into a new era of AI.

Looking back on the competition:

- I beat over 𝟑,𝟏𝟎𝟎 submissions from over 45,500 developers, which included solo developers like myself, teams of seasoned industry veterans, and even entire companies
- I beat submissions from 𝟏𝟏𝟗 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬, from Canada to Korea to India
- I spent 𝟐 𝐦𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐡𝐬 locked in my room over the summer before coming to college developing Jayu
- My demo video on YouTube received overwhelming support without any advertisement, raking in over 𝟒,𝟒𝟎𝟎 𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰𝐬 and over 𝟐𝟎𝟎 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞𝐬
- I had 𝟒 𝐂𝐄𝐎𝐬 reach out for technical advice, and many more students from around the world in my email and LinkedIn expressing their excitement
- I had over 5 mental breakdowns while developing this app and couldn’t sleep properly for months due to stress…

The journey was scary, to say the least. As a solo developer, Jayu was more than my passion project. Jayu was literally my heart and soul. I cannot find the words to properly thank everyone who supported me on my journey. So to my 𝐞𝐧𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐨𝐮𝐬 team of reviewers who I forced to watch my demo video again and again until it was perfect, thank you.

- To my best friend Matthew Rodrigues, thank you for always being there and letting me use your backyard for filming.
- USACO Platinum Reviewers: Abhinav Arunkumar, Justin Osbey
- UCLA Researcher Reviewers: William Jiang, Daniel Wu
- To my dear friends who reviewed my demo: Joseph Hoang, Jan Andrei Ordonez, Alden Santoso, Sunny Vinay, Eric Ziyang Zhou, Johnny Zheng, Eshan Velidandla, Kavya Desai, Ishaan Desai, Elysia Du, Ethan Chen, Allyson Li, John Tacuchi, Eric Ju, Clara Yee, Arnav Bhola
- Tech Influencer Reviewer: Arash Joobandi

And most importantly, thank you Lloyd-Bryant Hightower for organizing and communicating with all of us competitors in the competition! And thank you to the teams at Google for selecting me as the winner.

Logan Abbott
        
              
          Nurses Say Hospital Adoption of Half-Cooked 'AI' Is Reckless: An anonymous reader quotes a report from Techdirt: Last week, hundreds of nurses protested the implementation of sloppy AI into hospital systems in front of Kaiser Permanente. Their primary concern: that systems incapable of empathy are being integrated into an already dysfunctional sector without much thought toward patient care: "No computer, no AI can replace a human touch," said Amy Grewal, a registered nurse. "It cannot hold your loved one's hand. You cannot teach a computer how to have empathy."

There are certainly roles automation can play in easing strain on a sector full of burnout after COVID, particularly when it comes to administrative tasks. The concern, as with other industries dominated by executives with poor judgement, is that this is being used as a justification by for-profit hospital systems to cut corners further. From a National Nurses United blog post (spotted by 404 Media): "Nurses are not against scientific or technological advancement, but we will not accept algorithms replacing the expertise, experience, holistic, and hands-on approach we bring to patient care," they added.

Kaiser Permanente, for its part, insists it's simply leveraging "state-of-the-art tools and technologies that support our mission of providing high-quality, affordable health care to best meet our members' and patients' needs." The company claims its "Advance Alert" AI monitoring system -- which algorithmically analyzes patient data every hour -- has the potential to save upwards of 500 lives a year. The problem is that healthcare giants' primary obligation no longer appears to reside with patients, but with their financial results. And, that's even true in non-profit healthcare providers. That is seen in the form of cut corners, worse service, and an assault on already over-taxed labor via lower pay and higher workload (curiously, it never seems to impact outsized high-level executive compensation).

Read more of this story at Slashdot.

Listen in as we discuss topics from his new book, "The Skill Code: How to Save Human Ability in an Age of Intelligent Machines," exploring how AI can be a partner to augment human skills, the role of digital apprenticeship in practical skill development, and the nuanced challenges of technology integration that benefit experts but may inadvertently impact novices.

          𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿'𝘀 𝗔𝗽𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝗵: 𝗣𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗔𝗜 𝗔𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝘁 𝗖𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗮 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘁𝗵𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲

As an engineer with a computer science background, I've always been drawn to the practical application of cutting-edge technology. At Carta, we're pushing the boundaries of what I call "Applied AI" – harnessing existing LLMs to solve real-world problems in innovative ways.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗠𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀𝗲𝘁

In a broad oversimplification, scientists explore and discover, engineers take existing innovations and apply them. The best do it in creative and new ways. This symbiotic relationship drives progress, and it's the philosophy I’ve pushed Carta Healthcare to embraced in our AI initiatives.

𝗢𝘂𝗿 𝗔𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗲𝗱 𝗔𝗜 𝗝𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘆

Last week marked a significant milestone: the 5th iteration of our AI solution went live in production. In our field, real-world testing is crucial – we need actual medical data to validate accuracy. This is because we can’t move medical data off production systems without massive and error prone sanitization methodology that destroys the data quality most time. 

𝗘𝘅𝗰𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀
The results? Our AI-generated answers showed a remarkably high correlation with expert-provided solutions. This success has surpassed our expectations and confirms we're on the right track.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁'𝘀 𝗡𝗲𝘅𝘁?

We're maintaining an aggressive development pace, deploying updates weekly. Last week we also completed the set of MVP features needed to introduce our AI software – a huge milestone for my engineering teams. We can’t wait to get their feedback!!!!

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝗼𝗳 𝗣𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗜𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

This journey underscores the impact of applying cutting-edge technology to real-world challenges. As we continue to refine and expand our AI capabilities, I'm excited to see how it will transform our industry and improve outcomes for our users.
 
𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩𝘵𝘴 𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘱𝘳𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘭 𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘭𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘰𝘧 𝘈𝘐 𝘪𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘧𝘪𝘦𝘭𝘥? 𝘐'𝘥 𝘭𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘩𝘦𝘢𝘳 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘴 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴 𝘣𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘸.

Last May, I embarked on an incredible journey with WisdomAI right after graduating from UIUC, and it has been nothing short of a dream run! Starting my career with a passionate, dynamic team like this one has been an amazing experience. 🚀

Here’s what I’ve absolutely loved about my time at WisdomAI so far:

1️⃣ Ownership Sparks Passion
When you’re empowered with the right motivation and a sense of ownership, the task transforms into a pursuit. I’ve cherished the freedom to take charge of my projects, driven by curiosity for achieving results rather than just deadlines.

2️⃣ Culture of Growth & Impact
I’m deeply grateful to the founders and my team for cultivating an environment of insane growth while delivering great value to our customers every single day. Huge thanks to the founders - Soham, Sharvanath, Kapil, and Guilherme for fostering this environment.

3️⃣ The Power of Team Energy
The motivation and drive of the people around you can make all the difference. Being surrounded by such an energetic, supportive team has truly set the trajectory for my career. 

As we step into this new year, we’re doubling down with more energy, sharper focus, and even bigger goals for our startup. Here’s to a year of innovation, impact, and scaling new heights together! 💡🌍



#StartupJourney #GrowthMindset #WisdomAI #Teamwork #Innovation #NewYearGoals #CareerJourney

Selin Kocalar
        
              
          Since the YC deadline to hear back for W25 is coming up next week, here’s the story of how we went from 2 students coding in an MIT dorm room to being full-time YC founders building Delve in SF.

For all you founders anxiously waiting to hear back, just keep building — you’ll be successful regardless of the decision.

--

In Fall 2023, my co-founder Karun Kaushik and I were studying AI at MIT and spending all of our free time building an AI medical scribe to help doctors. We had vaguely heard about YC from a friend who had just gotten accepted but had no plans of applying whatsoever.

However when the YC deadline rolled around, we spontaneously decided to put in an application on the very last day. We spent that whole day in Karun’s dorm room typing up the application and filming all the required videos. We finally hit submit the minute of the deadline!

By the next day we had already moved on. We went back to the usual rhythm of coding in the dorm room, calling with doctors, attending conferences, etc. If anything, we were even more motivated now to get more traction and be successful regardless.

Later that week, while we were eating in the dorm kitchen, I noticed I got an email saying we had a YC interview scheduled. My heart rate spiked. I jumped up out of my seat and immediately told Karun. I never seriously considered YC, but for the first time it hit me that it might actually be a possibility.

When the day of the interview rolled around, we did mock interviews with former YC founders and focused mostly on calming our nerves. More important than the actual content of the interview, we wanted to show our excitement for building and hacking together as co-founders.

Unfortunately the interview caught us by surprise. The group partners didn't seem to care as much about our actual AI medical scribe. Instead, they seemed more curious about a side idea we had listed in our application that we wrote up in a day. The idea was about streamlining HIPAA compliance (since we had to go through HIPAA for our AI medical scribe).

By this point, we were already seriously considering pivoting into this and had made a lot of progress on the idea. The YC interview was our tipping point

Not too long after, we got an ominous email titled “YC.” We were freaked out. I could not sleep the entire night. Then, in the middle of class the next day, I got a phone call from Karun with Surbhi on the other end of the line. My heart rate spiked. I ran outside of the classroom.

That turned out to be our acceptance call:)

--

For everyone out there still waiting to hear back, just keep grinding. Build as if you’ve been rejected and you might just be pleasantly surprised.

I’m also always here to help with mock interviews/give advice! We’ve helped a handful of friends through the YC app process and are always here to support other founders!

Nishant Pandey
        
              
          Optimize for 🚀 Bio Cores First, Silicon 🤖 Cores Second

David Heinemeier Hansson makes a compelling case: prioritize human programmers (bio cores) over computer processing power (silicon cores).

Here’s why it matters:
👉 Investing in programmer efficiency is far more valuable than solely optimizing for computer speed. 
👉 Human labor costs far exceed computing costs. Boosting human productivity should be the main focus. 
👉 In the age of AI and high-level programming languages, the bio cores drive your real gains.

Bottom line: Make your programmers more productive, and watch your team (and tech) thrive.

Read the full article here:  https://lnkd.in/gK8HEGtk

 P.S. :  The image below is brilliantly summarized using Napkin.ai for a quick visual breakdown.

Vidhyanand (Vick) Mahase PharmD, PhD.
        
              
          Kate Glazko, a graduate student at the University of Washington, discovered during her internship search that recruiters often use AI tools to summarize resumes and rank candidates. A study found that these AI tools consistently ranked resumes with disability-related credentials lower than those without, revealing a bias against disabled individuals. Researchers attempted to mitigate this bias by customizing the tool with specific instructions to avoid ableism, but the improvements were minimal for certain disabilities. The findings were presented at the 2024 ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency. Jennifer Mankoff, a professor in the Allen School at UW, emphasizes the need for further research on AI biases and their impact on job seekers. Some organizations are working to improve outcomes for disabled job seekers, highlighting the necessity for continuous customization and testing of AI systems to address these biases.
https://lnkd.in/ePShRiXN

          As part of the 2023 George B. Krishiv Thakuria
        
              
          When I spent the summer in San Francisco, I was shocked to find myself in a culture where many people dismissed artists. 

There's a real status divide between technical and non-technical people in SF, with artists especially being overlooked.

Everyone in SF knows tech is powerful, but too many people in SF underestimate the power art holds in society too. 

Ironically, understanding that would help them build better technology.

Because rapid AI progress means taste has never been more important to make your products stand out.

Few understand this because of legacy startup advice which I believe doesn't hold true (or as true) today.

For example, Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn once said "If you aren't embarrassed by the first version of your product, you shipped too late." 

But LinkedIn was founded in 2002.

And things have really changed in the last 2 decades.

Consumers have never been more unforgiving. As a result, the bar for aesthetics and design in technology has never been higher.

As I build out the AI teddy bears I've been working on, I constantly remind myself that functionality is just a start, and making people truly feel something is the goal.

I want to build technology that people hold like art.

Steve Jobs is a phenomenal example of someone who did just that (which I believe was a large contributor to Apple's success).

“It is in Apple’s DNA that technology alone is not enough—it’s technology married with liberal arts, married with the humanities, that yields us the results that make our heart sing.”

The value of great taste increases as progress in AI increases.

And artists will soon have the spotlight in San Francisco too.

          It’s been a while since I last posted, so I thought I’d share a few things I’ve been working/worked on over the past 6-7 months:

1)Building a Custom Compiler 
After getting really interested in Compiler Design last semester, I took it upon myself to learn how to implement a custom compiler. Spent my summer vacation building different stages of compilation. Honestly, it was challenging but super rewarding.(will be posting about in depth)

2) Exploring Vision Transformers
As part of an academic project on diabetic retinopathy. I dived deep into these models and learned a lot about computer vision. 

3)Web Scrapers for Placement Forums
Built a few web scrapers for scraping placement-related forums. Unfortunately, I lost the code because I forgot to push it to GitHub before formatting my laptop (tough lesson learned here).

4)YouTube Watch Party App
I’ve been working on a YouTube Watch Party app to learn WebSockets and WebRTC. It’s nearly finished—just needs a few final touches and some code cleanup before I host it. This project has been a great way to test out some ideas.

5)DSA Practice
Solved 400+ problems(Leetcode,GFG,Codeforces)—not something to brag about, given the market conditions, but it’s part of staying sharp in DSA.

6)Static Site Generator in Python
Currently working on a Static Site Generator in Python as part of Boot.dev’s course. It’s been fun to build, and I’m learning more about how static sites work under the hood.

A couple of things I couldn't finish (but plan to get back to):

1)Redis Clone (C++ - Codecrafters)
Got through 22/40 tasks but hit a nasty bug that I couldn’t figure out(skills issues!!). Will take it up again when I have more time (or when I level up my debugging skills!).

2)Next.js Application Tracker
Started building an app to track all my applications in one place. Definitely want to pick this back up when I have a bit more bandwidth.

Jennifer Mena
        
              
          🚀 Day 2 of the Headstarter AI Software Engineering Fellowship was thought-provoking with Faizan Ahmed and Jack O'Brien! Here are some of my favorite insights:

🔹 "Distribution eats product for breakfast" – Emphasize growth product features and leverage short-form content on platforms like TikTok and Instagram to capture attention.

🔹 Building relationships with startups:
Platforms like Y Combinator can help find promising startups that may resonate with our education, interests or experience.
Focus on building rapport, testing their products, and offering constructive feedback.

📌 Tips to build a project from scratch:
Waitlists are great: Create a landing page, test engagement with a basic MVP, or provide free credits to gather emails from interested users.
Blogging and meetings: Write valuable blog posts and network in real life.

💡 Jack O’Brien’s tips:
Side projects: Critical for career growth. His personal examples, like a presentation platform for startups and an environmental calculator, were inspiring and motivating. Don’t obsess over the “idea”; just choose a decent one and start practicing.
Getting first users: Work on projects that excite you, involve friends, and share on as many platforms as possible.
Using AI to code: Embrace tools like Cursor AI and ChatGPT, but ensure you understand what your code is doing.

The overall takeaway was to get in the reps! This event was insightful and inspiring, and I’ll take action on these tips. Thank you, Faizan and Jack, for this great event! Excited for what's next in the program!

#HeadstarterAI

Mirza Baig
        
              
          1️⃣2️⃣ Takeaways from Mofi Rahman's Talk with Headstarter AI SWE Fellows:
I recently attended a session with Mofi Rahman, a Developer Relations Engineer from Google, and Headstarter AI's CEO, Yasin Ehsan 🚀 at a Headstarter AI fellows meeting. Mofi shared invaluable insights from his career journey and practical advice for aspiring software engineers. Here are 12 things I learned:

1️⃣ Background and Journey 🛤️
Career Path: Mofi graduated in 2017 from City College of New York and held roles at IBM, Vonage, and now Google, focusing on Kubernetes and AI/ML workloads.

2️⃣ Hackathon Experience 🏆
Participation and Judging: Participated in 20-30 hackathons as a student and judged 30-40 more. Fellows should actively join hackathons for skill-building and networking.

3️⃣ Industry Insights 🌐
Broad Scope: Software engineering spans multiple industries. AI tools boost productivity but require a solid foundation. Fellows should broaden their industry knowledge.

4️⃣ Challenges in the Job Market 🚧
Increased Competition: The job market is tough. Fellows should focus on building strong portfolios and staying updated with industry trends.

5️⃣ Effective Learning 🧠
Practical Approach: Learning should be problem-driven. Fellows should engage in iterative learning through building and breaking projects.

6️⃣ Team Collaboration 🤝
Diverse Skill Sets: Successful teams have diverse skills. Fellows should seek team members with complementary skills and collaborate effectively.

7️⃣ Accountability and Structure 🗂️
Structured Programs: Programs like Headstarter AI provide accountability and structure, essential for consistent progress. Fellows should leverage these programs fully.

8️⃣ Navigating Career Paths 🚀
Multiple Tracks: Headstarter offers tracks for tech leadership, individual contributors, and entrepreneurs. Fellows should align their efforts with their career goals.

9️⃣ Learning AI 🤖
Practical Projects: Start with practical projects using tools like LangChain and Llama Index. Fellows will complete 5 AI projects in 7 weeks!

🔟 Building Effective Teams 🛠️
Non-Glorious Tasks: Teams succeed when members handle essential tasks. Fellows should be willing to take on all roles in a project.

1️⃣1️⃣ Career Advice 🎯
Networking and Collaboration: Actively network and participate in discussions. Set and prioritize long-term career goals.

1️⃣2️⃣ Feedback and Iteration 🔄
Continuous Improvement: Regularly seek and provide feedback. Embrace challenges to grow skills.

Mofi Rahman’s insights are invaluable for anyone looking to succeed in the software engineering field, Thanks Mofi Rahman! 🧠🤝🏽

Looking forward to learning more from Top SWE Panels every Thursday night during Headstarter AI's Pathways to Tech Events in the Fellowship Community. Shoutout to Yasin Ehsan 🚀 & Faizan Ahmed for putting this all together ! 🤝🏽✅

 #HeadstarterAI #CareerAdvice #SoftwareEngineering #AI #Hackathons #TeamCollaboration #Google #SWE
(H.AI.OK Track Day 1 of Posting ✅)

          🚀 Excited to share my completed Project 2 for the HeadStarter AI SWE Fellowship! 🎉

I’ve developed a Pantry Tracker app using Next.js, Material UI, and Firestore. Key features include:

🔹 Low Stock Alerts: Background color turns red for items with a quantity below 4.
🔹 Search Functionality: Easily filter items by name to quickly find what you need.
🔹 Item Management: Increase, decrease, and delete buttons for straightforward updates to your inventory.
🔹 Upcoming Enhancements: Plan to add a login page for enhanced security and some improvement on the user interface.

Due to a challenging health issue that led to my hospitalization, there was a delay in submission. I’m now recovering and back on track! 

Check out the app and video demo here:  https://lnkd.in/gRsHZvWd

Big thanks to the Headstarter team and Bill Zhang for the invaluable support!

#HeadStarterAI #SoftwareEngineering #NextJS #MaterialUI #Firebase #AppDevelopment #TechCommunity

Jim Blomo
        
              
          "Why did Santa's AI-driven sleigh keep running into trees?"

So much 🔥 from Julie Wang and John Allard in today’s OpenAI live stream! They covered Reinforcement Fine-Tuning, medical research, and shared some truly punny jokes. Moments like these remind me why I love my team: brilliant people solving fascinating problems—and having fun along the way! https://lnkd.in/gJnNiTXc

If you'd like to participate in the Research Program by sharing data, check out https://lnkd.in/gZYehx9T or ping me.

Reinforcement Fine-Tuning is a new technique for teaching the new models how to reason. It's kinda like how AlphaGo taught a model how to play by "grading" games, then learning what "good" moves are by comparing moves in winning vs losing games. This opens up a whole new paradigm for models, where you're not just teaching them the answer, but teaching them how to arrive at the right answer.

What is Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (RFT)?
It’s a groundbreaking technique for teaching models how to reason. Think of it like AlphaGo: the model learns by being “graded” on games and understanding what makes moves in winning games better than losing ones.

With RFT, prompts are like the “games” and chain-of-thought reasoning is like the “moves.” By evaluating the "winning" reasoning steps, the model learns which ones lead to better answers. This means we’re not just teaching models the answers—we’re teaching them how to think through problems and consistently arrive at the right solutions.

My team’s mission is simple: give you the world’s best model for your domain. If you’re finding it hard to get API responses to work for your business—whether it’s a performance issue, cost concern, or accuracy challenge—let me know. We have tools to improve outcomes, and I love working with customers to see how we can do even more.

Oh, and Santa’s sleigh? Julie gave us the answer: “Because he hadn’t ‘pine’-tuned yet!” 🥁
